text: During the chaos of the Trump years, the big running joke was that the New York Times kept reporting about UFOs, and that was still one of the least shocking news events during that chaotic time.
And so how did you get, as a longtime reporter for the Times, how did you get into the UFO
And how did you get UFOs on the front page of the New York Times in 2020?
Well, 2017, it started.
Right.
But 2020 was the big, like, gasp reveal.
Yeah.

Well, we got it in in 2020 because we had broken the ground in 2017 with that big front page story about ATIP, you know, the secret Pentagon unit that was investigating UFOs that no one knew about until we broke the story on the front page of the Times.
After that, we had some follow ups, including in 2020, where we talked about close encounters, close calls, Navy jets almost colliding with some of these UFOs.
And finally, we just kind of broke the story that Congress or committees in Congress were briefed on materials, OK, quote, very difficult story to get, and we can talk about that in more detail.
You know, and that was in the height of the Trump craziness, breaking that story.
So but that that was really the trajectory.
We did a number of stories starting in 2017.
And how did your colleagues react to you working on these stories all these years?
Well, we're mixed.
You know, we were the butt of some jokes, some joking in the Washington bureau, particularly Helene Cooper, who collaborated with Leslie Kane and me on the first story.
She was and is the Pentagon correspondent.
So she took some heat from her colleagues.
They would go, you know, da, da, da, da, da, da, da, da, you know, when she would pass in the newsroom.

But when she showed some of the videos that we had gotten from the Navy that showed these UFOs and we actually broke, you know, the news of these videos in The New York Times, when she pulled some of those up on her computer, everybody, you know, in the Washington bureau crowded around and they were they were mesmerized.
They wanted to see that.
Oh, my God, what's that?
So I think basically, we had got a lot of support from our colleagues.
Yeah, I mean, it's a tough, taboo subject.
And you can just define for our listeners what exactly are UFOs?
Well, UAP is really what the Pentagon likes to call them, unidentified aerial phenomena, UFOs, unidentified flying objects.
And, you know, people say, do you believe in UFOs?
You don't have to believe in UFOs.
They're unidentified.
You know, there's something up there that they can't identify.
And some of them, you know, a number have been explained, can be explained.
You know, various natural phenomena, clouds, you know, all kinds of things.
But a great number of them cannot.
And the big the last big Pentagon, you know, investigation, Operation Blue Book, which ended in 1969, which concluded, you know, that it was nothing to see here.
But there were 701 cases left on the table that they couldn't explain.
So, you know, add to those 701 cases, then thousands since then.
And you know, we're left with we're left with a big mystery.
These things.
And now the Pentagon says that they're real.
I mean, we don't know what they are.
Nobody knows what they are, where they come from, what they want.
You know, what intelligence, if any, is behind the wheel.
But at least now the government is saying, well, these things have a physicality.
They're real.
They're not a hallucination.
They're not a mistake.
You know, they're not a fraud or a hoax.
So in that sense, we've come a long way.
A recent government report said that it can't be ruled out that they're not aliens.
From all the reporting you've done, all the conversations you had, how likely do you think some of these UAPs, UFOs, are aliens?
Well, you know, that's a question that the government just won't address, by the way.
They don't go there.
And I understand that.
It's one step at a time.
And it is pure speculation.

But if you figure that the aerodynamics of these objects are not like anything seen on Earth, that we, the American government, the experts, don't believe that any earthly adversary is capable of this kind of advanced technology.
I mean, these things had no, you know, aerodynamic surfaces, no wings, no tails, no propellers, no exhaust, no sound, no rivets.
You know, I mean, it just defied explanation.

And certainly these objects seemed not to be anything that anyone on Earth was capable of in terms of their speed, their maneuverability, their ability to disappear and appear, operate even underwater in some cases.
They seem to go into the water and out of the water, not just the atmosphere.
So then you say, well, who could be behind these?
I mean, that's pure speculation.
But one of the possibilities would have to be that there's some kind of alien intelligence operating them either robotically or on board.
But I mean, you cannot exclude that possibility, obviously.
So that's where we're left.
I mean, you know, nobody has the proof.
Nobody has any evidence.
These whoever, whatever might be behind these things has not been caught on, you know, any recording device.
So it remains a mystery.
When I bring this topic up, as I like to do, I always point folks to your reporting and all the work that you've done in this area.
I get the pushback.
Well, if there is intelligent life, there are such a thing as aliens among us visiting Earth.
What would they possibly what would an advanced intelligence possibly want with us?
Yeah, that's a good question.
You know, John Mack, the Harvard psychiatrist who is the subject of the book I wrote when he was asked this question in different ways, he had a good answer.
He said, you know, I'm a human psychiatrist.
I'm not an alien psychiatrist.
I cannot figure out their motivations, you know, what they might be thinking or why they you know, why did they appear in this famous episode we can talk about in Zimbabwe in 1995?
There was some kind of a landing, according to 60 school kids who saw it.
But no adults saw it at the time.
So people kept saying, well, how come no adults saw this?
You know, 60 kids at recess all saw this craft land and two beings as they described it later.
And they drew pictures and all the kids sort of agreed.
I mean, not exactly.
It wasn't a story that they all subscribed to, but they told us similar accounts.
And these were very innocent kids.
They weren't conniving together to make up a story.
And when they went to John Mack and said, well, how come no adults, you know, the aliens picked the one time when the kids were at recess and no adults were present?
You know, how do you explain that?
And he said, look, I'm not an alien psychiatrist.
You know, I can't I can't explain these things.
It's just what the kids reported.

So what they want from us, if they're so if there's technology so superior, are we are they curious the way we are curious about animals, you know, inferior forms of life that they would like to study?
Who knows?
But as I said, the important thing is that these objects forget about aliens because we don't know about aliens, but the objects themselves are real.
So there are things in the atmosphere that seem to be under intelligent control that we cannot explain that much.
We now think we know.
So, you know, why they do it this way, why they're here, all good questions.
And how likely is it that it could be China, Russia or any or Israel or any other country?
Yeah, very unlike I mean, to the point of impossible.
I mean, again, based on the look, I mean, there are drones around.

We know that there's some very sophisticated technology flying around the balloon episode that we recently, you know, were privy to the Chinese called Weather Balloon, Surveillance Balloon, whatever it was, floating into our atmosphere territory.
So there is some sophisticated technology out there, that's for sure.
But that doesn't explain the kind of things that pilots like Dave Fravor, a very highly decorated Navy pilot and Alex Dietrich, his wing person.
But they encountered these things and they are the most they were the most sophisticated, you know, technologically gifted observers we have in this country.
The subject, you know, the recipient of millions of dollars of training and and expertise.
And they saw these things, tic-tacs, they called them.

And that didn't did not seem possible that they could be Chinese technology or Russian or Iranian or Israeli, just not possible, given what we know of the the physics and the ability we have or we understand to the way objects move.
It just does not seem possible.

So that's why the experts that we've talked to at The New York Times, that The New York Times has talked to in the Pentagon and, you know, for our reporting have all said that it is unlikely to the point of impossibility that at least all these things can be explained by earthly adversaries.
Because they tend to defy the laws of physics as we know them.
As we as we understand them.
Right.
I mean, physicists will tell you you can't defy the laws of physics.
You know, those are the natural laws.
But it's as we understand the laws of physics, physics, you know, laws.
I mean, before Einstein, we thought physics took certain forms.
After Einstein, we realized that it took other forms.
So we may not just understand all the possibilities.
You'd have to be a moron to think we understand everything there is to know about physics right now, that there's nothing left to find out.
No, no serious person will tell you that.
There's a lot we still don't understand, a huge amount, obviously.
So there may be things that could explain the movements, you know, the operations of these objects.
But we don't understand that yet.
It's certainly a Galileo moment that challenges the conventional thinking and deals with all sorts of skepticism out there.
Absolutely.

One explanation I heard from a researcher at the Pentagon or had been at the Pentagon for some time, one theory is that the intelligent life form driving these extraordinary machines, crafts, whatever you want to call them, one of the reasons why they want nothing to do with us, it's the same sort of question.

If you were to go back in time and suddenly find yourself among a bunch of, I would say, like Templar knights during the Crusades or people are being burned alive and just the savagery of human beings, basically, that this other life form is just so advanced compared to us that they don't really want to mess with us.

So, you know, like you use the animal reference, but it's also a time traveler not wanting to spook the people of the Middle Ages at risk of, you know, being harmed, being burned at the stake or whatever.
And also this person touched on the fact, saying that there's a lot of interest around water with these crafts.
There's a lot of sightings around water.
There tends to be some of the crafts.
And that there's a theory that maybe Earth is just a far flung fueling station for them to go to other places.
Yeah, there was a lot in that question, Andrea.
Well, this is like a therapeutic conversation for me.
I can finally talk to somebody.
You know, you say, well, they want nothing to do with us.
And yet they, whatever they, whoever they are, are here.
You know, I mean, they're all over the place.
They've been sighted in every country on Earth, just about every continent to all kinds of people for a very long time.
So if they don't want anything to do with us, why don't they just stay away from Earth?
But there's something that that draws these these things, you know, to to our area of the of the galaxy of the universe.
So, you know, why they're here, I mean, that's a good question.

They certainly have not gone out of their way to announce themselves or I shouldn't say that they have announced themselves, but they haven't made themselves transparent or clear what what they want, whatever it is they haven't, you know, introduced themselves to our leaders as far as we know, although there's a lot of stories out there about, you know, strange collaborations with American government, which, you know, you can find on the Internet.
We can we can try to unpack that.
There's certainly no evidence of that.
There's just stories.
But anyway, you know, that's really one of the mysteries.
Why, if they don't want anything to do with us, why are they here?
What do they want if they're so advanced that they can, you know, master this kind of technology?
What do they want with us?
Maybe there's something missing from them that they're looking for in us.
Well, did John Mackett close to answering that?
He didn't get close.
He raised a lot of good questions.
What he what he did is he compiled a lot of data from people who consulted him.
I don't even want to call them patients because there was nothing wrong with them.

OK, but hundreds of people told their stories to John Mack about encounters that they believed they had and not only believed, but that they that in some cases third parties confirmed they had with these beings, whatever you want to call them.
So he compiled a lot of data.
He never figured it out.
And all he did was provide a kind of a good database of experiences that people recounted to him, you know, both consciously and sometimes under deep, you know, under relaxation techniques.
He wasn't a big fan of hypnosis like like Bud Hopkins and other people.
But anyway, he got all these accounts and they were very, very similar accounts.
They were not similar to the point that, you know, everybody was telling one story that they kind of agreed on.
But there was a similarity to the stories that convinced him that they had all experienced something that could not be explained.
But in the end, again, you know, you got to come away from this phenomenon with great humility.
It remains unexplained.
